awd_titl_txt: Implementing the STEM Excellence and Leadership Program to Understand the Role of Local Agency in Broadening High-Potential, Rural Students' STEM Participation and Achievement
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative research, approaches and resources for use in a variety of settings. This Research in Service to Practice project will address the issues around Informal Education of rural middle school students who have high potential regarding academic success in efforts to promote computer and IT knowledge, advanced quantitative knowledge, and STEM skills. Ten school districts in rural Iowa will be chosen for this study. It is anticipated that new knowledge on rural informal education will be generated to benefit the Nation's workforce. The specific objectives are to understand how informal STEM learning shapes the academic and psychosocial outcomes of rural, high-potential students, and to identify key characteristics of successful informal STEM learning environments for rural, high-potential students and their teachers. The results of this project will provide new tools for educators to increase the flow of underserved students into STEM from economically-disadvantaged rural settings. 

The President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology predicts a rapid rise in the number of STEM jobs available in the next decade, describing an urgent need for students' educational opportunities to prepare them for this workforce. In 2014, 62% of CEOs of major US corporations reported challenges filling positions requiring advanced computer and information technology knowledge. The project team will use a mixed methods approach, integrating comparative case study and mixed effects longitudinal methods, to study the Excellence program. Data sources include teacher interviews, classroom observations, and student assessments of academic aptitude and psychosocial outcomes. The analysis and evaluation of the program will be grounded in understanding the local efforts of school districts to build curriculum responsive to the demands of their high-potential student body. The project design, and subsequent analysis plan, utilizes a mixed methods approach, incorporating case study and longitudinal quantitative methods to analyze naturalistic data and build robust evidence for the implementation and impact of this program. This project will provide significant insights in how best to design, implement, and support informal out-of-school learning environments to broaden participation in the highest levels of STEM education and careers for under-resourced rural students.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
The University of Iowa College of Education Belin-Blank Center for Gifted Education and Talent Development (B-BC) received a $1.9 million Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) Research in Service to Practice award to implement and evaluate the STEM Excellence and Leadership Program (STEM Excellence) in ten rural school districts in rural Iowa. The project goal was to advance the evidence-base around practices that optimally support the STEM achievement of rural, high-potential students. Over five years, the project reached 841 students and 40 educators in geographically diverse rural schools and produced 6 peer-reviewed publications and 11 conference proceedings.

 

The design of the STEM Excellence program directly addressed the critical need to provide students in under-resourced rural schools with STEM learning opportunities that foster student growth in STEM knowledge, skills, and interests. National data consistently shows that rural students lack access to advanced STEM coursework such as AP science, computer science, and mathematics during high school and lag in post-secondary enrollment compared to their urban and suburban peers (29.1% rural v. 44.1% non-rural). When rural students do pursue higher education, they are less likely to pursue and attain STEM degrees. Nurturing STEM talent prior to high school years becomes paramount to prepare rural students for future success in STEM fields. Research is clear; informal STEM learning environments offer a unique and important pathway to develop rural STEM talent as it connects STEM learning to students? lived experiences and local community.

Guided by the talent search model for talent identification and development (Assouline & Lupkowski-Shoplik, 2012), STEM Excellence was designed to 1) enhance K-12 educators? ability to identify and prepare rural, high-potential students for advanced mathematics and science classes; 2) adapt middle-school mathematics and science curricula for out-of-school learning environments; and 3) boost high-potential middle-school students? preparation for and achievement in the highest-level mathematics and science classes in high school and beyond. Key program components included intensive programming (96 hours) in mathematics and science to rural 6-8th grade students outside of the formal classroom and ongoing professional development for STEM educators (2-day immersive on-campus PD during the summer and continued technical assistance during the academic year). The university-school partnership between B-BC and participating districts was another key component of the program. The project team collected student survey data, educator interviews, and conducted observations of informal learning using the Dimensions of Success protocol to evaluate the design, implementation, and outcomes of STEM Excellence.

From the research and evaluation, we identified three key project outcomes around 1) talent identification, 2) program innovation, and 3) participant engagement. STEM Excellence gave rural educators the assessment tools to identify more students ready for advanced coursework. In the first year of the program, almost triple the number of students were identified as having high-potential in STEM across the ten rural districts (13% v. 5%). Second, the project team developed a collaborative process to guide rural educators on how to design a place-based, locally responsive informal STEM learning program. Educators had a great degree of flexibility in the program design at each district. They were also supported in designing programs that were responsive to the needs and interests of the students in the program. Many educators worked with community partners to find ways to sustain the program after the end of the grant. Finally, students reported an increase in their curiosity, enjoyment, satisfaction, and self-efficacy in STEM because of participating in the program. Educators also observed how student engagement in STEM Excellence improved student motivation in the formal classroom environment. A core theme across our findings was the importance of leveraging rural community assets and empowering rural educators and students to build STEM communities of practice.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/21/2023
Modified by: Susan G Assouline
